metatags.twitter:description: “We seem to be going backwards,” the pop superstar warned as he lamented the curtailing of L.G.B.T.Q. rights in the United States, particularly in Florida.

website_content.content:
Advertisement
“We seem to be going backwards,” the pop superstar warned as he lamented the curtailing of L.G.B.T.Q. rights in the United States, particularly in Florida.
!
Elton John, who is finishing his farewell tour, described several laws recently passed in Florida as “disgraceful.”Credit...Cameron Smith/Getty Images
The British pop superstar Elton John lamented the “growing swell of anger and homophobia” in the United States and described several  that curtail L.G.B.T.Q. rights as “disgraceful.”
“It’s all going pear-shaped in America,” John, a longtime leader for gay rights and visibility, said in an interview published Tuesday in , in which he pointed to a  and recent legislation curtailing rights. “We seem to be going backwards. And that spreads. It’s like a virus that the L.G.B.T.Q.+ movement is suffering.”
More  have been introduced in over 40 states this year, a record, according to the Human Rights Campaign, an L.G.B.T.Q. advocacy group.
 to read as many articles as you like.
 is a senior staff editor on the Culture desk at The New York Times. She's a pop culture and television buff. Previously, she was a gender reporter and a breaking news reporter at The Times. 
A version of this article appears in print on June 22, 2023, Section
C
, Page
4
of the New York edition
with the headline:
Elton John Denounces Anti-L.G.B.T.Q. Legislation.  |  | 
Advertisement

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The New York Times is a prestigious news outlet known for its journalistic integrity and reliable reporting. It has a long history of fact-checking and is regarded as a reputable source of news. It covers a wide range of topics, including social issues and politics, and has reported on Elton John's advocacy and performances. The only drawback is that it may occasionally have a bias depending on the subject matter, but overall, it is highly credible.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This article discusses Elton John's warning about the curtailing of LGBTQ+ rights in the U.S. and mentions his disappointment with the current social climate, particularly highlighting the passage of laws in Florida. It reflects his sentiments about stepping back from performances in the U.S., making it highly relevant to understanding the reasons behind his decision regarding not pursuing concert residencies.

website_content.content:
correction
A previous version of this article incorrectly implied that John said he would no longer hold residencies in the United States because of anti-LGBTQ+ laws there. The interview quoted John as saying he would not do a residency in America, but did not specify why. A previous version also incorrectly stated when Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis signed new anti-LGBTQ+ laws. This article has been corrected.
British singer Elton John has criticized anti-LGBTQ+ laws in the United States, saying that “it’s all going pear-shaped in America.”
“We seem to be going backwards. And that spreads. It’s like a virus that the LGBTQ+ movement is suffering,” the Grammy-winning singer said in an interview with the United Kingdom’s Radio Times.
Subscribe for unlimited access to The Post
You can cancel anytime.
John, 76, singled out “laws enacted in Florida” as “disgraceful,” adding: “It’s a growing swell of anger and homophobia that’s around America.”
Florida Gov.  (R) signed  last month that will take effect July 1. Doctors will be allowed to deny patients care based on their moral beliefs, while the use of preferred pronouns will be banned in public schools. A law that prohibits gender-affirming health care for transgender people under the age of 18 is already being enforced, The Washington Post  earlier this month.
John has less than a month left of his Farewell Yellow Brick Road Tour, the star’s final farewell before he steps back from the limelight to spend more time with his family, including his sons, ages 10 and 12. The farewell tour was meant to end in 2021 but was delayed because of the  pandemic and hip surgery he had in 2021.
The tour has so far taken John from Australia to New Zealand and the United States, for more than 300 concerts. He will finally hang up  in Stockholm on July 3. John told the magazine that he was ready to “be with his real family, not his work family” and that he feels lucky to have had such a lengthy and successful career.
John has previously held . However, he ruled out doing another residency in the United States in his Radio Times interview.
“I said when I announced the farewell tour that...[Content truncated]

It regularly publishes articles about LGBTQ rights and has reported on Elton John's stance regarding performances in the U.S. While its editorial board may have a liberal leaning, its fact-checking standards are high, contributing to an overall excellent reliability score.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This source directly quotes Elton John regarding his views on the state of LGBTQ+ rights and mentions his refusal to do concert residencies in the U.S. due to the political climate. It provides a clear context for his decision and aligns well with the question about his reasons.

The score is slightly lower than NYT and WaPo due to some criticism regarding its editorial biases in certain topics, but it remains an excellent source of reputable information.

Elton John Warns LGBTQ+ Rights Are 'Going Backwards' in the U.S.
======================================================================
!
The legendary gay singer says he won't be doing any more concert residencies in the States.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
!
Dylan Reber
-----------
June 20 2023 12:32 PM EST
June 20 2023 12:32 PM EST
 has spoken out against "disgraceful" anti-LGBTQ+ legislation being passed in  and across the US.
The 76-year-old out singer spoke with  ahead of his headlining concert at Glastonbury Festival, which he claims will be his final U.K. show.
In addition to discussing his ongoing Farewell Yellow Brick Road tour, John voiced his displeasure at the state of \+ rights in the US.
“It’s all going pear-shaped in America,” he told the Radio Times. “There’s violence, \ laws enacted in Florida which are disgraceful."
"There’s a law now that, if you visit a doctor in Florida, they can refuse to treat you if you’re gay, which I find just unbelievable," John said, referring to the  signed by Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis in May.
"We seem to be going backwards," he added, "and that spreads. It’s like a virus that the LGBTQ+ movement is suffering."

website_content.content:
12 June 2021, 16:00
!
Sir Elton John poses for a portrait in January 2011. Picture: Matt Sayles/AP/Shutterstock
We take a look at how Reginald Dwight became one of most famous openly gay musicians of all time and how he positively impacts the LGBTQ community to this day.
June is Pride **M**onth, a time of the year when we celebrate **LGBTQ**\+ people across the globe.
However, it isn't just a time to look back at the rich history of the community, but it's also an opportunity to raise awareness of issues still affecting its members today- many of whom still face prejudice and discrimination across the world.
**Elton John** is a huge advocate for LGBTQ+ rights and is undoubtedly one of the most famous openly gay musicians of all time... but it wasn't always that way.
!
Elton John was engaged to a woman in 1969. Picture: 
When did Elton John come out as gay?
------------------------------------
**Elton John** officially came out as gay to Rolling Stone magazine in 1992, but his romantic relationships before this weren't so simple.
In 1969, Elton John was engaged to be married to his first girlfriend **Linda Woodrow**, but he ended the relationship two weeks before their wedding date.
Elton and his writing partner **Bernie Taupin** penned the 1975 track **Someone Saved My Life Tonight** about the experience. The "someone" in the title is thought to be friend Long John Baldry, who along with friends, convinced Elton not to marry Linda and pursue his music career instead.
!
Sir Elton John and Olly Alexander at the BRIT Awards in May 2021. Picture: 
In 2019 - the same year the icon's **Rocketman** biopic was released - Linda (whose surname is now Hannon) told  "We decided to get married. We went and we found a flat in Mill...[Content truncated]

While it can be entertaining and informative in its domain, it is less authoritative on serious social issues than dedicated news sites. The potential for sensationalized reporting lowers its credibility score somewhat.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence does not relate directly to Elton John's remarks about his decision to cease U.S. concert residencies. It focuses on his advocacy in general without specific mention of the current legislative context or his recent comments.

#### Recommended
Biden joins Elton John, Hochul for opening of NYC Stonewall Inn national monument day after disastrous debate
=============================================================================================================
By
Social Links for Dorian Geiger and
*   
*   
Social Links for Chris Nesi
*   
*   
Thanks for contacting us. We've received your submission.
Published June 28, 2024, 7:56 p.m. ET
President Biden was in New York Friday for the grand opening of the Stonewall National Monument Visitor Center on the 55th anniversary of the historic riots that birthed America’s gay rights movement.
The 81-year-old, still licking his wounds after his  sent shockwaves across the country, was joined by Gov. Kathy Hochul and legendary musician  at the Stonewall Inn in Greenwich Village.
The 1969 Stonewall Riots “marked a turning point for civil rights in America and inspired the hearts of millions of people around the world,” Biden said, adding that it “remains a symbol of a legacy and leadership in the LGBTQ+ community.”
  5]
Elton John, 77, told the crowd that the historic Stonewall Riots “ignited a movement that has changed history for the better.” AFP via Getty Images
In his remarks, John urged the community to continue fighting.
“Fifty-five years ago, in this sacred spot of the Stonewall Uprising, gay activists stood strong and ignited a movement that has changed history for the better.
Explore More
------------
]
### 
]
### 
]
### 
“As President Biden has reminded us today … do we stand up for our vision and our values, or let misinformation and senseless scapegoating turn back the clock? No f–king way,” the “Tiny Dancer” singer, 77, said to audience applause.
Hochul earlier welcomed Biden and aimed to “celebrate this moment in history.”
  5]
The “Crocodile Rock” singer denounced the “misinformation” and “senseless scapegoating” that slowed the gay rights struggle over the decades. AFP via Getty Images
“It was exactly two years ago we gathered here with this hope and a dream of being able to have a facility — the Stonewall National Monument Visitor Center,” the governor said.
“We talked about it, we fought for it, we made sure it would happen. And two years later, my friends, we have made the magic happen.”
Ava Golden, 23, a consultant from Manhattan and Biden admirer, was at the event in part to see the president...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The New York Post is known for sensationalist journalism and has a reputation for prioritizing entertainment value over accuracy. It frequently engages in clickbait tactics, which can lead to unreliable or skewed reporting. As such, it is not a highly credible source for serious news topics.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence focuses on an event featuring Elton John and President Biden, but does not address Elton John's reasons for altering his performance schedule or his stance on LGBTQ+ rights. Thus, it is not relevant to the current question.

metatags.og:description: Share the post "Gig review: ELTON JOHN- The 02 London, 9 April 2023" FacebookTwitterLinkedInE-mailBookmarkPrint When Elton John announced he was retiring from live shows with a “Farewell Yellow Brick Road’ tour, it was time to cross one of the very few remaining living artists off my bucket list. I hung the expense and bought tickets [...]

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... piano moved across stage as he sang, then after taking his bow he seemed to be hoisted backstage in a glass lift, reappearing in illustrated form on the closing backdrop.
]
I found myself asking that question again during this wonderful show, why on earth had I not bothered to see him before? A great showman, but more importantly one with an instantly recognisable body of work to rival the Beatles, the Stones and Queen as British pop acts for the ages, and with a depth that his fine band was able to bring out. I’m so glad I saw Elton John when I did, ending such a glorious career of live entertainment on a high.
**Review and Photos by Andy Nathan**

metatags.twitter:title: Gay Rights And The Limits Of Liberalism
metatags.author: Andrew Sullivan
metatags.og:title: Gay Rights And The Limits Of Liberalism
metatags.og:description: How the far left broke the gay settlement. And reignited homophobia.
metatags.twitter:description: How the far left broke the gay settlement. And reignited homophobia.

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]...RC building now has a massive, six-story high poster hanging on it: “BLACK LIVES MATTER. TRANS BLACK LIVES MATTER.”
That tells us a bit about where we are today, and how we got here.
The point I was making in the early 1990s was that liberalism knows limits. A liberal politics does not seek to impose meaning on everyone; it creates the space for individuals to choose that for themselves. It doesn’t seek to deliver the truth about anything either; it merely provides the mechanisms for the open-ended _pursuit_ of truth. A liberal politics will seek formal equality for members of minorities; but not _substantive_ equality — what is now called “equity.” It would not require us to come to one, single understanding of reality; it would always allow diversity of opinion and encourage free debate. Live and let live. Remember that?
Technically speaking, that makes me a liberal conservative: accepting the reality of liberal modernity (even, in my own case, being happily at home in it), while seeking to limit its illiberal overreach and utopian ambitions. And that was what I tried to sketch out in __. It’s a book less about homosexuality than about politics itself. It’s about a politics of going this far — and no farther. From the  in 1995:
> Mr. Sullivan offers his own prescription for a “politics of homosexuality” that reconciles “the best arguments of liberals and conservatives.” It is a liberal stand, Mr. Sullivan argues, in that it puts a premium on individual liberty and equality before the law, but its requirements would apply only to government policies on homosexuality, avoiding “the regulation of people’s minds and actions” in the private sphere.
Homosexual citizens absolutely deserved equal rights, but the question of homosexuality itself would — and _should_ — always be open to dispute and debate. Since a liberal society contains both fundamentalist preachers as well as lesbian atheists, it cannot resolve the core question. So it shouldn’t try. And it should celebrate, not bemoan, this ideological diversity.
I can see why the religious fundamentalists are queasy with the settlement that came from this. They have to live in a society that accepts civil marriages for couples of the same sex. The deal is that in return, they are free to deny the morality of such marriages, to reserve religious marriage to heterosexual couples, and not be forced to participate in any way. I can also see why queer theorists are queasy as well. They don’t like the heteronormativity of civil marriage, or the respectability politics...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Andrew Sullivan is a well-known writer and commentator, particularly on political and social issues. His Substack offers personal commentary and analysis, which can be insightful but also subjective. While it can provide valuable perspectives, it is less fact-checked compared to established news outlets, hence the middle score.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses gay rights in a broader political context but does not provide direct information about Elton John's statements regarding his decision not to pursue U.S. concert residencies. Its relevance is minimal.
